ocr_text: Ateneo de Manila University Institute of Engineering Research TERMINAL REPORT sonst, Management Office Study Title: Digital Literacy in Philippine Basic Education Researcher: Christina Jenkins, Dawn Carter, Ellen Jimenez Implementing Agency: Department of Science and Technology (DOST) Duration: July 2024 August 2025 1 Executive Summary This research examines sustainability practices and environmental awareness among university students in Metro Manila, providing critical insights into the current state of environmental consciousness in Philippine higher education. The study surveyed 2 500 students across ten major universities and conducted in depth interviews with environmental science faculty, student organization leaders, and campus sustainability coordinators. Findings reveal a growing awareness of environmental issues among Filipino youth, with 78% of respondents expressing concern about climate change and its impact on the Philippines. However, the study identifies a significant gap between awareness and actual sustainable practices in daily life. While students demonstrate knowledge of environmental concepts, implementation of sustainable behaviors such as waste segregation, energy conservation, and sustainable transportation remains inconsistent. The research highlights successful campus initiatives including green building programs, waste management systems, tree planting activities, and environmental advocacy ‘campaigns organized by student groups. Notable practices include the integration of sustainability principles into university curricula, establishment of eco friendly campus facilities, and partnerships with local government units for community based environmental projects. Key recommendations emphasize the need for stronger institutional commitment to sustainability, integration of environmental education across all disciplines, provision of infrastructure that enables sustainable practices, and creation of incentive systems that encourage eco friendly behavior among students and staff. ocr_text: University of the Philippines School of Economics Research TERMINAL REPORT Division Study Title: Digital Literacy in Philippine Basic Education Researcher: Ashley Gonzales, Christina Anderson, Amy Donaldson Implementing Agency: Depariment of Education (DepEd) Research Management Service Duration: November 2023 October 2024 Executive Summary This comprehensive study analyzes the employability of graduates from Philippine higher education institutions and assesses the alignment between academic programs and industry requirements. The research involved collaboration with over 200 companies, 30 universities, and included surveys of 5 000 recent graduates and 500 employers across various sectors. Results indicate a concerning mismatch between graduate competencies and industry expectations, with ‘employers reporting that 45% of fresh graduates require substantial additional training before becoming productive employees. Key skill gaps identified include critical thinking and problem solving abilities, communication and interpersonal skills, adaptability and innovation, and practical application of theoretical knowledge. The study examines successful university industry partnership models, work integrated learning programs, and curriculum development initiatives that demonstrate improved graduate outcomes. Notable examples include cooperative education programs, industry sponsored capstone projects, internship and practicum arrangements, and industry advisory board involvement in curriculum design. Recommendations emphasize the need for stronger collaboration between academe and industry, regular curriculum review and updating processes, enhanced experiential learning opportunities, development of soft skills alongside technical competencies, and establishment of graduate tracer studies to monitor employment outcomes and inform program improvements. BU F RDMD 06 Effective November 08, 2025 Page 1 of 29 Page 1 of 1 Rev 3 1

ocr_text: De La Salle University Institute of Engineering Research ‘TERMINAL REPORT Management Office Study Title: Mental Health Services Assessment in Philippine Colleges Researcher: Lisa Delgado, Holly Hoffman Implementing Agency: Department of Science and Technology (DOST) Duration: November 2023 June 2025 L Executive Summary This research project investigates the current state of digital literacy and technology integration across Philippine basic education institutions, examining the readiness of schools, teachers, and students for 21st century learning demands. The study covered 150 public and private schools Nationwide, involving comprehensive assessments of technological infrastructure, teacher Competencies, and student digital skills. Findings demonstrate significant disparities in digital literacy levels between urban and rural schools, with Metro Manila and major urban centers showing substantially higher rates of technology adoption and integration. The research identifies ctitical factors affecting successful technology integration, including availability of devices and internet connectivity, teacher training and professional development, administrative support, and alignment with curriculum standards. The study reveals that while the Department of Education has implemented various programs to enhance digital literacy, implementation challenges persist due to limited resources, inadequate training opportunities for educators, and lack of sustainable maintenance systems for technological equipment. However, successful case studies from innovative schools demonstrate the transformative potential of effective technology integration when supported by comprehensive planning and stakeholder commitment. Recommendations include development of a national digital literacy framework, increased investment in educational technology infrastructure, establishment of sustained teacher training programs, creation of locally relevant digital learning resources, and formation of public private partnerships to address Tesource gaps. The research emphasizes the critical importance of digital literacy in preparing Filipino students for future workforce demands and global competitiveness. BU F RDMD 06 Effective a September 26, 2025 sevens Page tof 1 Page 1 of 29

Recommendations include development of a national digital literacy framework, increased investment in educational technology infrastructure, establishment of sustained teacher training programs, creation of locally relevant digital learning resources, and formation of public private partnerships to address resource gaps. The research emphasizes the critical importance of digital iteracy in preparing Filipino students for future workforce demands and global competitiveness. ocr_text: University of the Philippines Graduate School Research Ethics TERMINAL REPORT ‘Study Title: Quality Assurance in Higher Education Institutions Researcher: Joy Payne, Kendra Robertson, Heather Molina, Crystal Cruz Implementing Agency: Commission on Higher Education (CHED) Duration: December 2023 May 2025 L _ Executive Summary This research examines sustainability practices and environmental awareness among university students in Metro Manila, providing critical insights into the current state of environmental consciousness in Philippine higher education. The study surveyed 2 500 students across ten major universities and conducted in depth interviews with environmental science faculty, student organization leaders, and campus sustainability coordinators. Findings reveal a growing awareness of environmental issues among Filipino youth, with 78% of respondents expressing concern about climate change and its impact on the Philippines. However, the study identifies a significant gap between awareness and actual sustainable practices in daily fe. While students demonstrate knowledge of environmental concepts, implementation of sustainable behaviors ‘such as waste segregation, energy conservation, and sustainable transportation remains inconsistent. The research highlights successful campus initiatives including green building programs, waste management systems, tree planting activities, and environmental advocacy Campaigns organized by student groups. Notable practices include the integration of sustainability principles into university curricula, establishment of eco friendly campus facilities, and partnerships with local government units for community based environmental projects. Key recommendations emphasize the need for stronger institutional commitment to sustainability integration of environmental education across all disciplines, provision of infrastructure that enables sustainable practices, and creation of incentive systems that encourage eco friendly behavior among students and staff. ocr_text: University of Santo Tomas College of Social Sciences Center TERMINAL REPORT for Policy Studies Study Tit Community Based Disaster Risk Management Researcher: Karen Rojas, Gabrielle Tate, Amy Munoz Implementing Agene National Research Council of the Philippines (NRCP) Duration: January 2024 August 2024 1. Executive Summary This terminal report presents findings from a comprehensive assessment of mental health services and support systems available to students in Philippine colleges and universities. The research was conducted across fifteen institutions representing diverse geographical locations and institutional types, including state universities, private colleges, and sectarian schools. The study employed multiple research methodologies including surveys administered to 3 000 students, interviews with counseling center staff and mental health professionals, and analysis of institutional policies and programs. Results indicate alarming statistics regarding student mental health, with 42% of respondents reporting experiencing moderate to severe anxiety, 35% reporting symptoms of depression, and 28% indicating academic stress affecting their overall wellbeing. Assessment of existing mental health support systems reveals significant gaps in service provision. While larger institutions maintain counseling centers with licensed professionals, many smaller colleges lack adequate mental health resources. The student to counselor ratio in most institutions exceeds recommended standards, with an average of one counselor serving 3 000 to 5 000 students. Furthermore, stigma surrounding mental health issues continues to prevent many students from seeking help. The research documents innovative programs and best practices, including peer counseling initiatives, mental health awareness campaigns, stress management workshops, and integration of mental health education into orientation programs. Recommendations include increased funding for mental health services, training programs for faculty to recognize and respond to student mental health concerns, development of crisis intervention protocols, and creation of supportive campus environments that prioritize student wellbeing BU F RDMD 06 Effective P: October 12, 2025 of 29 Page 1 of 1 Rev 2 1

Office of the Vice President for ‘TERMINAL REPORT ‘Study Title: Community Based Disaster Risk Management Researcher: Kimberly Peterson, Molly Cabrera, Kristi Cline Implementing Agency: Department of Education (DepEd) Research Management Service Duration: July 2024 May 2025 1 Executive Summary This comprehensive research study investigates the multifaceted impact of online learning modalities on student academic performance across various disciplines in Philippine higher education institutions. The research employed a mixed methods approach, combining quantitative analysis of academic records with qualitative interviews and focus group discussions involving students, faculty members, and administrators from six major universities in Metro Manila and key regional areas. The study reveals significant findings regarding the adaptation of students and educators to digital learning platforms, highlighting both challenges and opportunities in the Philippine educational context. Key findings indicate that while access to technology and internet connectivity remains a critical barrier for many students, particularly those from rural and economically disadvantaged backgrounds, innovative solutions and institutional support mechanisms have enabled successful learning outcomes. The research identifies several factors that contribute to academic success in online learning environments, including student self regulation, faculty training and preparedness, institutional infrastructure, and the quality of learning management systems. Data analysis shows varying levels of adaptation across different academic disciplines, with STEM fields facing unique challenges compared to humanities and social sciences programs. Recommendations include the development of comprehensive digital literacy programs, investment in robust technological infrastructure, Creation of inclusive policies that address the digital divide, and continuous professional development for educators. The study also proposes a framework for sustainable online and blended learning implementation that considers the socio economic realities of Philippine ‘education. ocr_text: University of the Philippines Dilimpn Graduate School Research Ethics TERMINAL REPORT Committee ‘Study Title: Indigenous Knowledge Systems in Agriculture Researcher: Morgan Parker, Holly Hensley, Danielle Carlson, Megan Adams Implementing Agency: Department of Education (DepEd) Research Management Service Duration: December 2023 December 2025 1 _ Executive Summary This terminal report presents findings from a comprehensive assessment of mental health services and support systems available to students in Philippine colleges and universities. The research was conducted across fifteen institutions representing diverse geographical locations and institutional types, including state universities, private colleges, and sectarian schools. The study employed multiple research methodologies including surveys administered to 3 000 students, interviews with counseling center staff and mental health professionals, and analysis of institutional policies and programs. Results indicate alarming statistics regarding student mental health, with 42% of respondents reporting experiencing moderate to severe anxiety, 35% reporting symptoms of depression, and 28% indicating academic stress affecting their overall wellbeing. Assessment of existing mental health support systems reveals significant gaps in service provision. While larger institutions maintain counseling centers with licensed professionals, many smaller colleges lack adequate mental health resources. The sstudent to counselor ratio in most institutions exceeds recommended standards, with an average of one counselor serving 3 000 to 5 000 students. Furthermore, stigma surrounding mental health issues continues to prevent many students from seeking help. The research documents innovative programs and best practices, including peer counseling initiatives, mental health awareness campaigns, stress management workshops, and integration of mental health ‘education into orientation programs. Recommendations include increased funding for mental health services, training programs for faculty to recognize and respond to student mental health concems, development of crisis intervention protocols, and creation of supportive campus environments that prioritize student wellbeing, ‘BU F RDMD 06 Effective _ _ Page of 29 September 15, 2025 page tot Revi 4

Research Center Espafia Boulevard, Sampaloc, Manila 1015 research ust edu ph (02) 8731 4031 SS Terminal Report RESEARCH TERMINAL REPORT AND PROJECT CLOSEOUT Dear Dean, This letter formally transmits the terminal report and final documentation for the research project “Digital Literacy in Basic Education” which has been successfully completed as of July 24, 2026. The multi year research initiative, funded by National Research Council of the Philippines and conducted by our esteemed faculty researchers, has produced substantial scholarly contributions and practical recommendations relevant to Philippine development. The comprehensive terminal report encompasses research methodology, findings, analysis, and policy recommendations that meet international research standards. Throughout the project duration of August 2024 to July 2026, the research team maintained Consistent progress, regularly submitting interim reports and participating in monitoring and evaluation activities. The project achieved all specified milestones, including community engagement, stakeholder consultations, and dissemination of preliminary findings. Notable achievements include capacity building for junior researchers, establishment of research databases and repositories, development of research instruments that can be used by other scholars, and creation of networks with national and intemational research institutions. These outcomes extend beyond immediate research objectives and contribute to institutional capability enhancement. Financial management was conducted with utmost transparency and accountability. Regular audits confirmed compliance with funding agency regulations and institutional financial policies. All procurement followed proper procedures, and project expenditures were justified and documented appropriately. This project demonstrates our institution s capability to undertake large scale research addressing complex societal challenges. We look forward to continued collaboration with funding agencies and research partners in future endeavors. Respectfully yours, Prepared by DAVID wooD Dean Noted GRACE FRANK Dean

ocr_text: POLYTECHNIC UNIVERSITY OF THE PHILIPPINES. snd Develonment Office 3, Mania 1016 Anonas Terminal Report TERMINAL REPORT SUBMISSION AND RESEARCH COMPLETION NOTICE, Dear Director, This letter serves as formal notification of the successful completion of the research project titled "Climate Change Adaptation Study" conducted under the auspices of this institution and funded by Department of Education Research Office. The research team, led by Jeremy Bennett and comprising distinguished faculty members, has successfully completed all project deliverables within the stipulated timeline of March 2024 to March 2026. The terminal report, executive summary, and all supplementary documentation have been prepared in accordance with institutional and funding agency requirements. Key accomplishments of this research include comprehensive data collection and analysis, publication ready manuscripts, policy recommendations, and practical applications relevant to Philippine higher education and development priorties. The findings contribute significantly to the body of knowledge in this field and provide actionable insights for stakeholders. All financial obligations have been settled, and the final accounting report has been submitted to the Finance Office. Equipment procured through project funds has been properly inventoried and transferred to the appropriate academic units for continued institutional Use. We express our sincere gratitude for the institutional support provided throughout the project duration. The research outcomes reflect positively on our institution s commitment to academic excellence and community service. Respectfully submitted, ROSE SIMPSON ProgramD Noted EDGAR JOHNSON Director

ocr_text: UNIVERSITY OF SANTO TOMAS Graduate School Research Canter Espafia Boulevard, Sampaloc, Manila 1015 research ust edu ph (02) 8731 4031 Terminal Report COMPLETION CERTIFICATE FOR RESEARCH GRANT PROJECT Dear Dean, This letter formally transmits the terminal report and final documentation for the research project, “Disaster Risk Management Research” which has been successfully completed as of February 14, 2026. The multi year research initiative, funded by National Research Council of the Philippines and conducted by our esteemed faculty researchers, has produced substantial scholarly contributions and practical recommendations, relevant to Philippine development. The comprehensive terminal report encompasses research methodology, findings, analysis, and policy recommendations that meet international research standards. Throughout the project duration of February 2024 to February 2026, the research team maintained consistent progress, regularly submitting interim reports and participating in monitoring and evaluation activities. The project achieved all specified milestones, including community engagement, stakeholder consultations, and dissemination of preliminary findings. Notable achievements include capacity building for junior researchers, establishment of research databases and repositories, development of research instruments that can be used by other scholars, and creation of networks with national and international research institutions. These outcomes extend beyond immediate research objectives and contribute to institutional capability enhancement. Financial management was ‘conducted with utmost transparency and accountability. Regular audits confirmed compliance with funding agency regulations and institutional financial policies. All procurement followed proper procedures, and project expenditures were justified and documented appropriately. This project demonstrates our institution s capability to undertake large scale research addressing complex societal challenges. We look forward to continued collaboration with funding agencies and research partners in future endeavors. Respectfully yours, Prepared by MICHAEL WRIGHT Dean Noted COREY MARTINEZ Dean
